item.title: The Micro Center at Crescent Hills
item.description:
Jan 12

If you’re near a city, Micro Centers are good places to find computer parts. I’ve been eyeing this place on RR patrols for a while. Tucked back in the Crescent Hills shopping center off Highway 57, seventeen miles due west of Heron Outpost, RU-20. Looks to have been totally forgotten. No signs of vandalism or destruction. Full inventory. Here I was able to acquire a Raspberry Pi 5, monitor, keyboard, and a 32GB microSD card. Brand new in box.

Overview

Welcome to Phase 01 of the ZAC project.

This is where it all begins, so if you don’t know your ass from your elbow, don’t worry, you’re in the right place.

The goal of Phase 01 is to build a proof of concept (POC) — a small, working version of ZAC that shows us how all the hardware and software pieces fit together. It also lets us sanity-check the whole idea, because the jury’s still out on that one.

item.title: Zombie
item.description:
A human who has become something not quite human.

The zombie’s behavior is erratic to a harmful degree, retaining knowledge and memories from before the turn, but disconnected. It generally follows the same routine as it did in life, but its actions have been described as “jumbled and wrong somehow”. Absurd.

item.title: GPS
item.description:
Global Positioning System

A satellite-based navigation system that provides location and time information anywhere on Earth. ZAC uses GPS combined with offline maps to enable navigation without internet connectivity.

item.title: Lazarus Internet Archive
item.description:
LIA

A distributed network preserving a snapshot of the internet from before The Turning. Maintained by The Lazarus Collective, LIA is available through both official and unofficial mirrors throughout the world. Once connected, you can access canonical urls through your browser of choice.

item.title: Local LLM
item.description:
Large Language Model

An AI system that runs entirely on-device, requiring no internet connection. ZAC uses a local LLM to answer questions, assist with survival scenarios, and provide information from its offline knowledge base.

item.title: LoRa
item.description:
Long Range

A low-power, long-range radio communication protocol ideal for off-grid messaging. ZAC uses LoRa via Meshtastic-compatible devices to form mesh networks that can relay messages across kilometers without cellular or internet infrastructure.

item.title: Meshtastic
item.description: An open-source mesh networking project that runs on LoRa radio hardware. Enables off-grid text messaging, GPS location sharing, and telemetry between devices over distances of several kilometers. ZAC communicates with any Meshtastic-compatible device, creating decentralized communication networks that don’t rely on cell towers or internet.

item.title: Pelican
item.description: A brand of rugged, watertight, crushproof protective cases originally designed for sensitive equipment. ZAC lives inside a Pelican case to ensure survival in harsh conditions—dust, water, and impact.

item.title: Raspberry Pi
item.description: A low-cost, credit card-sized single-board computer developed by the Raspberry Pi Foundation. ZAC is built around the Raspberry Pi 5, chosen for its balance of performance, power efficiency, and widespread availability of replacement parts.

item.title: SDR
item.description:
Software Defined Radio

A radio receiver where signal processing is handled by software rather than dedicated hardware. Allows ZAC to monitor aircraft transponders (ADS-B), decode weather satellite imagery, and receive emergency broadcasts using a single USB dongle.

item.title: The Lazarus Collective
item.description: An organization based in Asheville, North Carolina, whose goal is to restore useful tools and technology from the old world. They maintain LIA, the Lazarus Internet Archive.

item.title: The Turning
item.description:
The worldwide phenomenon of human beings changing into something not quite human. This ongoing transformation has collapsed the social order. The root cause remains unknown, though scientists throughout the world continue to seek a cure.

See also, Zombie.

item.title: USB
item.description:
Universal Serial Bus

A standard connector for peripherals and data transfer. ZAC uses USB ports to connect sensor modules, SDR dongles, storage devices, and other expansion hardware—keeping the system modular and field-serviceable.

item.title: Wikipedia
item.description: A free, collaborative online encyclopedia. ZAC carries a compressed offline copy of Wikipedia, providing access to millions of articles without internet connectivity.

item.title: ZAC
item.description:
Zombie Apocalypse Computer aka Zero-Infrastructure Autonomous Computer

A resilient, off-grid computing system designed to survive and operate during catastrophic infrastructure collapse. Built with longevity, repairability, and energy independence as core principles.

ZAC runs ZACOS.

item.title: ZACLOG
item.description: The build series documenting the ZAC project from concept to field-ready system. Each entry covers a specific aspect of the build: hardware assembly, software configuration, testing, and deployment.

item.title: ZACLOG/00.00 - The Zombie Apocalypse Computer
item.description:
Or, the Zero-Infrastructure Autonomous Computer, if you prefer.

I just call it ZAC.

A self-contained, open-source survival computer designed to function completely off-grid.

Built around a Raspberry Pi architecture, ZAC lives in a weatherproof Pelican case. Solar and battery powered. No internet required. No cloud dependencies. No subscriptions. A standalone, civilization-in-a-box machine, constructed to outlast the zombie apocalypse.

item.title: ZACOS
item.description:
ZAC Operating System

The open-source application that powers ZAC. Mother brain. Provides a unified interface for offline AI, mesh communication, radio monitoring, navigation, and environmental sensing. Built to run entirely without internet connectivity.

Old Man: The ZACOS setup process currently requires access to LIA in order to download software packages. Realizing this is not ideal for fully-autonomous bootstrapping, I have been working on ways to distribute these files with ZACOS itself. In the meantime, if you are unable to access LIA mirrors, email oldman@zombieapocalypse.tech and I’ll find a way to get the files to you.
